title: Monospace composite characters
content:
I'm looking for nice examples of composite characters (Æ/æ/Œ/œ/Ĳ/ĳ) within monospace typefaces; especially more heavily grid-based ones.

Which typeface succeeds in putting two characters in the space of one, while maintaining the same look, feel, spacing & darkness?
author: neverblink

comments.content: I’d like to know that, too. IMHO, it can’t be done, since it would imply the double of darkness into one single slot.

One solution I have found is to reduce the weight of the stroke in the composite characters, so visually it has the same darkness as 'normal' characters.

This is [Capibara Mono](http://web.archive.org/web/20131021043408/http:/www.caketype.com/type/capibara_mono/index.html) by Caketype

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131021043408im_/http:/typophile.com/files/composite_5264.gif)
Yes, that could be a solution. Seems to work in text sizes (not so sure, though). But in bigger sizes it just looks too light.

![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131021043408im_/http:/typophile.com/files/amoeba_3567.png)
  
"m" has three verticals, likewise with the dipthongs.  
(Panoptica Doesburg shown.)
Nick, are you suggesting there is no problem?

It's the same problem as "m" if the face is reduced to a perpendicular grid.  
In another execution, such as a serifed, contrasted-stroke italic, it would be a different problem, and more of a problem:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131021043408im_/http:/typophile.com/files/amoeba2_3521.png)

I understand.

It might just be [my own design](http://web.archive.org/web/20131021043408/http:/i9.photobucket.com/albums/a70/neverblink/aeoeij.gif), that has an open feeling (and where the _M_ doesn't have three verticals), in which the combined characters seem to feel out of place.
